title: Missing X-XSS-Protection Header - Browser XSS Filter Bypass
description: The application does not set the X-XSS-Protection header in HTTP responses. This header instructs browsers to enable their built-in XSS filters and to block pages containing detected XSS attacks rather than attempting to sanitize them. While modern browsers (Chrome, Edge) have removed support for this header in favor of Content-Security-Policy, older browsers including Internet Explorer, older Safari versions, and other legacy browsers still support it. Missing this header reduces the defense-in-depth approach to XSS prevention and leaves users on older browsers vulnerable to reflected XSS attacks without browser-level protection.
impact:
Missing X-XSS-Protection header means:
- Older browsers (IE, older Safari versions) will not benefit from built-in XSS protection
- In browsers where reflected XSS exists, the browser won't actively block the attack
- Reduces defense-in-depth approach to XSS prevention
- Users on legacy browsers may be vulnerable to reflected XSS attacks
- While modern browsers have moved to CSP, this header provides additional protection layers
evidence:
POC execution confirmed the vulnerability across multiple HTTP methods:

GET Request - X-XSS-Protection: NOT PRESENT
HEAD Request - X-XSS-Protection: NOT PRESENT  
OPTIONS Request - X-XSS-Protection: NOT PRESENT

Sample response headers from http://localhost:5001:
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
Content-Length: 1093
Server: Werkzeug/1.0.1 Python/2.7.18
Date: Thu, 06 Nov 2025 21:21:10 GMT

No X-XSS-Protection header directive found in any response. The POC script execution returned exit code 0, confirming the vulnerability is present.
remediation:
1. Set X-XSS-Protection header in all HTTP responses:
   X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block

2. Implement in Flask/Werkzeug application:
   @app.after_request
   def set_security_headers(response):
       response.headers['X-XSS-Protection'] = '1; mode=block'
       return response

3. Verify the header is present:
   curl -i http://localhost:5001 | grep X-XSS-Protection
   Expected output: X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block

4. Additionally implement Content-Security-Policy for modern browsers:
   response.headers['Content-Security-Policy'] = "default-src 'self'"
   This is the recommended long-term solution that works in all modern browsers

5. Test the implementation:
   - GET /: Verify X-XSS-Protection header present
   - HEAD /: Verify X-XSS-Protection header present
   - OPTIONS /: Verify X-XSS-Protection header present
